question.title: Count Substrings That Can Be Rearranged to Contain a String II
question.content:
You are given two strings word1 and word2.

A string x is called valid if x can be rearranged to have word2 as a prefix.

Return the total number of valid substrings of word1.

Note that the memory limits in this problem are smaller than usual, so you must implement a solution with a linear runtime complexity.

 

Example 1:

Input: word1 = "bcca", word2 = "abc"

Output: 1

Explanation:

The only valid substring is "bcca" which can be rearranged to "abcc" having "abc" as a prefix.

Example 2:

Input: word1 = "abcabc", word2 = "abc"

Output: 10

Explanation:

All the substrings except substrings of size 1 and size 2 are valid.

Example 3:

Input: word1 = "abcabc", word2 = "aaabc"

Output: 0

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= word1.length <= 106
  • 1 <= word2.length <= 104
  • word1 and word2 consist only of lowercase English letters.
hints: Use sliding window along with two-pointer here.
Use constant space to store the frequency of characters.

rephrased.body: Given two strings, `word1` and `word2`, determine the number of substrings of `word1` that can be rearranged to have `word2` as a prefix. A substring is considered 'valid' if it can be rearranged such that `word2` is a prefix of the rearranged string. Return the total count of valid substrings of `word1`. Implement a solution with linear time complexity due to memory constraints.
constraints: word1 and word2 consist only of lowercase English letters.

testcases.explanation: The substring "bcca" can be rearranged to "abcc", which has "abc" as a prefix.
All substrings except those of length 1 and 2 are valid.
No substrings of word1 can be rearranged to have "aaabc" as a prefix.

hints: Use sliding window along with two-pointer here.
Use constant space to store the frequency of characters.
